title.rendered: This is the shape of govt finances, according to Budget 2023-24

content.rendered:
The current financial year has been choppy for economy with a number of economic and geopolitical challenges emerging for advanced as well as other economies. The happenings have been described as a “polycrisis”, a situation when disparate factors create a range of inter-linked crises. Recessionary fears, monetary tightening, the Ukraine war, global food and energy crisis, tensions over Taiwan, disrupted and shifting supply chains, pandemic recovery, etc. have together rocked the global economy ..
The fiscal deficit of the Union government, estimated at 9.2 per cent of GDP during the pandemic year FY 2020-21, moderated to 6.7 per cent of GDP in FY 2021-22 and is budgeted to decline further to 6.4 per cent of GDP in FY 2022-23. The fiscal deficit at the end of November 2022 stood at 58.9 per cent of the Budget Estimates (BE), lower than the five-year moving average of 104.6 per cent of BE during the same period.
The revenue deficit for April-November 2022 is 57.8 per cent of BE compared to the corresponding figure of 38.8 per cent in the previous year. After plummeting during the pandemic-affected year FY 2020-21, revenue receipts registered robust growth in FY 2021-22, driven by a rebound in the collection of all major direct and indirect taxes (except excise duties). Last year’s revenue buoyancy momentum is continuing into the current year. The Gross Tax Revenue registered a y-o-y growth of 15.5 per c ..
The total expenditure of the Union Government in FY 2020-21 rose to 17.7 per cent of GDP, higher than the previous 5-year average of 12.8 per cent of GDP. The government adopted a pragmatic approach of increasing its expenditure in a calibrated way. In the subsequent year, FY 2021-22, the total Union Government expenditure was 16 per cent of GDP and a larger proportion of this accrued to capital expenditure.
